constructs.name: Form placement
constructs.description: Form placement refers to the deliberate choice of surface: page, side panel, or modal, for presenting forms and multi-input tasks. The right surface depends on the complexity of the task, the amount of context the user needs from the current screen, and the level of disruption that is acceptable.

constructs.name: In-page navigation
constructs.description: In-page navigation is a navigational component for exploring content within a single page. Users can scan the page structure, jump directly to sections, and understand their current position as they scroll.

constructs.name: Intentional friction
constructs.description:
Design friction is the intentional use of obstacles in a user interface to prevent accidental or destructive mistakes. It should be used when a user is about to perform an action that is irreversible, such as deleting data or changing permanent system settings.

For high-risk tasks, use blocking friction like requiring the user to type a confirmation word or check a box acknowledging specific risks. For medium-risk or advanced settings, use non-blocking friction like warning dialogs or technical language to ensure the user is acting deliberately rather than clicking through mindlessly.

constructs.name: CTA block
constructs.description: The CTA (call to action) block presents one or more related actions that guide the user toward the next step within a section, such as learning more, making contact, or downloading a resource. It supports primary, secondary, and link-level CTA, all of which are optional and can be combined depending on the context. It provides a visually prominent way to highlight key next steps and should be used when you want to encourage decisive user engagement within a page or section.

constructs.name: Divided section
constructs.description: The divided section pattern is used to separate related content into distinct steps or items within a single section. Each item is visually divided using a muted [Rule](/divided-section#anatomy) and shallow padding, helping users distinguish between content blocks while maintaining a cohesive layout.

constructs.name: Data spotlight
constructs.description: The data spotlight pattern presents key statistics as the primary content, supported by short [Headline](/data-spotlight#anatomy)s and optional [Description](/data-spotlight#anatomy)s. It is designed to surface important numbers in a clear, scannable layout that helps users quickly understand impact, scale, or outcomes.

constructs.name: CTA section
constructs.description: The CTA section is a prominent and visually engaging section designed to encourage users to take a clear next step. It combines a concise copy and one or more call-to-action elements into a focused layout that stands out from surrounding content. This pattern is typically used mid-page or near the end of a page to re-engage users and guide them toward a specific action such as downloading resources, contacting sales, or exploring key documentation. The CTA section helps reduce decision friction by clearly communicating what the action is and why it matters now.

constructs.name: Blog
constructs.description: The blog pattern displays 3 to 4 blog articles in a grid layout. Each article shows a cover image, title, description, author information, and publication date. Articles can be loaded dynamically or provided statically. Designed to highlight recent contents in specific topic, the pattern offers users quick access to featured blog posts.

constructs.name: Basic section
constructs.description:
The Basic section is a two-column (50/50) layout pattern for presenting a single topic with a mix of content blocks. It can include text, images, videos, lists, code snippets, logos, and call-to-action elements. 

Choose this pattern to communicate a single topic that can be clearly conveyed in a side-by-side, two-column structure.

constructs.name: Tooltip
constructs.description: A tooltip is a small popup that displays helpful information or context when a user hovers over or focuses on an element, providing additional details without cluttering the interface.

constructs.name: Text area
constructs.description:
- Allows user to input multiple lines of text
- Used in cases where user needs to be able to provide longer form text. such as when writing a comment or note.

constructs.name: Tabs
constructs.description: A tabs component organizes related content into separate sections, allowing users to switch between different content panels within the same context by clicking on labeled tab headers. It helps reduce visual clutter by displaying only one content panel at a time while keeping all options easily accessible.

constructs.name: Table of contents
constructs.description: The table of contents is a navigational component consisting of a series of anchor links that correspond to sections within a page. When clicked, each link scrolls the user to the relevant section of content. This component is typically used on pages with substantial content, such as documentation or long-form articles, where users benefit from being able to quickly locate and jump to specific information without manually scrolling through the entire page.

constructs.name: Switch
constructs.description: A switch allows users to instantly change between two states (on/off, enabled/disabled). It provides immediate visual feedback and is commonly used for settings, preferences, or features that can be activated or deactivated with a single interaction.

constructs.name: Select
constructs.description: Select components allow users to choose a single option from a list of choices, mostly in forms. Selects are ideal when users need to pick from a predefined set of options where displaying all choices at once would consume too much screen space.

constructs.name: Segmented control
constructs.description: A segmented control allows users to toggle between alternate views of the same content, displaying only one view at a time. This component is commonly used to let users switch between different formats or representations of the same underlying data, such as viewing information as a table, a list, or a cards.

constructs.name: Search
constructs.description: The search component serves as the entry point to a search experience, allowing users to quickly find and access content by specifying a word or phrase rather than manually navigating through an interface. It is almost always used in conjunction with other components that enrich the search experience and display results. Search is well-suited for documentation sites, dashboards, and marketing websites where users need to locate specific items efficiently. Use this component when users would benefit from a faster alternative to manually browsing and scrolling through content.

constructs.name: Radio
constructs.description: Radios are used to select a single option from a group of mutually exclusive choices, commonly found in forms, settings, and preference panels. Unlike [Checkbox](/checkbox)es which allow multiple selections, radios ensure only one option can be selected at a time within each group.

constructs.name: Notification
constructs.description: Notifications display brief, contextual messages to inform users about system status, user actions, or important updates. They typically appear temporarily and can convey success, error, warning, or informational states to provide immediate feedback without disrupting the user's workflow.

constructs.name: Code
constructs.description: The code component displays code, commands, and technical language that requires distinct visual treatment. This includes programming languages, domain-specific languages such as search syntax, terminal commands, file paths, and configuration values.

constructs.name: Link
constructs.description:
Links are usually used for navigation. They connect users to different pages or sections in an interface. Navigational links can be embedded in body text, listed in footers, or integrated into [Breadcrumbs](/breadcrumbs) and other wayfinding components. 

Links can also prompt actions. They work best for actions that support but do not define the main user flow. Command links should clearly state that they lead to an action.

constructs.name: Input
constructs.description: The input component allows users to enter and edit text-based data. It provides a standardized interface for collecting user input such as names, email addresses, passwords and other textual information.

constructs.name: Divider
constructs.description: The divider is a vertical line used to separate content within an interface. It creates clear boundaries between distinct sections, helping users understand the structure and organization of information.

constructs.name: Contextual menu
constructs.description: A contextual menu provides secondary actions and options that can be attached to various interface controls, including [Button](/button)s, command [Link](/link)s, and right-click interactions. It displays relevant actions based on the context of the element or area it's associated with, helping to keep the interface clean while making additional functionality easily accessible when needed.

constructs.name: Chip
constructs.description:
Chips are visual elements that display information about a specific entity on the page. This information can be status, categories, tags, etc. 

They make this information more visually prominent and therefore elevate it in the information hierarchy.

In addition to displaying information, chips can also facilitate secondary actions such as content filtering, selection and highlighting. When interactive, chips maintain their primary function of displaying information - filter chips display applied filters while allowing dismissal, selection chips highlight selected options while allowing changes. Chips should not replace the primary call-to-action [Button](/button). They should be used for supporting actions that complement the main user flow rather than driving it.

constructs.name: Checkbox
constructs.description: Checkboxes are used to select items from lists or [Table](/table)s, and to enable/disable settings or features. Unlike [Switch](/switch), checkboxes typically require confirmation (such as pressing a "Save" [Button](/button)) before changes take effect, while [Switch](/switch)es apply changes immediately.

constructs.name: Button
constructs.description: Buttons trigger actions within an interface, typically involving data transformation or manipulation. They provide clear visual indicators of the primary actions users can perform on a page or section.

constructs.name: Breadcrumbs
constructs.description: Breadcrumbs are a navigational aid that shows users their current location within a site's information hierarchy. They provide a clear path from the root of the information hierarchy (IA) to the current page, allowing users to quickly understand where they are and easily navigate back to previous levels in the IA. Breadcrumbs should reflect the IA, not the user's path they took to arrive at the current page. They work best in websites or applications with multiple levels of hierarchy and are particularly useful when users might arrive at deep pages through [Search](/search) or [Link](/link)s.

constructs.name: Badge
constructs.description: A badge is a read-only visual indicator for numeric values. It is often used in other components to show for example a number of elements contained in that component.

constructs.name: Accordion
constructs.description:
The accordion is a vertically stacked content area which can be collapsed and expanded to reveal or hide its contents. An accordion can be opened or closed independently of its surrounding counterparts (i.e: multiple accordions can be open at the same time). 

When used right, accordions can help browse different pieces of related content in a more efficient way. Be wary that they can also hide content from users and are not suitable when a user is meant to read all of the page content.

constructs.name: Pagination
constructs.description: Pagination is a navigational component that allows users to move between pages of content. It provides controls for navigating to the previous or next page, as well as optionally jumping directly to a specific numbered page. This component is best suited for content-heavy sites where information is divided across multiple pages, such as blog posts, articles, tutorials, or [Search](/search) results. For paginating tabular data, use the Table pagination component instead.

concepts.name: Site
concepts.description: The complete web property or domain.

concepts.name: Bubble
concepts.description: A thematic cluster of related pages.

concepts.name: Page
concepts.description: A single URL-defined document containing navigation, content layout footer.

concepts.name: Content layout
concepts.description: Narrative structure, the structural pattern used to arrange sections.

concepts.name: Section
concepts.description: A cohesive content unit expressing one idea or purpose.

concepts.name: Block
concepts.description: A repeatable micro-structure with parallel content units.

concepts.name: UI component
concepts.description: A functional UI component from the design system.

concepts.name: Content primitive
concepts.description: The smallest meaningful authored content value.

concepts.name: Web design principles
concepts.description: These principles guide decision-making across marketing, web, and brand experiences. They provide a shared framework for clarity, coherence, and long-term maintainability of Canonical sites.

concepts.name: Content guide
concepts.description: Codification of our brand guidelines ensuring proper Canonical branding on Sites.

concepts.name: Color
concepts.description: Sites are using a predefined set of colors from the Design System palette. Color layering is also following a set of functional rules to ensure we apply the same visual choices across all our pages.

concepts.name: Spacing
concepts.description: Sites are using predefined vertical spacing tokens ensuring content is properly positioned and maintains vertical consistency.
